contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix =[[The Honourable]] | name = Kathy Sullivan | honorific-suffix =[[Order of Australia|AM]] | image = | office = [[Australian Senate|Senator]] for [[Queensland]] | term_start = 18 May 1974 | term_end = 5 November 1984 | successor = [[Warwick Parer]] | constituency_MP1 = [[Division of Moncrieff|Moncrieff]] | parliament1 = Australian | majority = | predecessor1 = ''New seat'' | successor1 = [[Steven Ciobo]] | term_start1 = 1 December 1984 | term_end1 = 8 October 2001 | birthname = Kathryn Jean Martin | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1942|3|8}} | birth_place = [[Brisbane, Queensland]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Australia]]n | spouse = | party = [[Liberal Party of Australia]] | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[University of Queensland]] | occupation = Teacher | profession = | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Kathryn Jean Martin "Kathy" Sullivan''' [[Order of Australia|AM]] (born 8 March 1942), [[Australia]]n politician, was a [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]] member of the [[Australian Senate]] from 1974 to 1984, representing [[Queensland]], and a member of the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] for the [[Division of Moncrieff]], Queensland, from 1984 to 2001.<ref name=parlbio>[http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;page=0;query=Kathy%20Sullivan;rec=0;resCount=Default Parliamentary profile]</ref> She served longer in the Australian Parliament than any other woman, oustripping the record previously held by [[Dorothy Tangney]]. She was the first woman member of the parliament to have served in both houses.<ref name=mccann>Dr Joy McCann and Janet Wilson (7 March 2012): [http://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Departments/Parliamentary_Library/pubs/BN/2011-2012/Womeninparliament Representation of women in Australian parliaments], Australian Parliamentary Library.</ref> Sullivan was born '''Kathryn Jean Martin''' in [[Brisbane]], Queensland, and was educated at the [[University of Queensland]], where she graduated in arts. She was a teacher, administrative officer and part-time lecturer before entering politics.<ref name=parlbio /> She was elected to the Senate at the [[Australian federal election, 1974|1974 election]], and sat as Senator Kathy Martin. She resigned from the Senate in 1984 in order to contest the newly created lower house seat of [[Division of Moncrieff|Moncrieff]] at the [[Australian federal election, 1984|1984 election]]. Soon after entering the House of Representatives she changed her name to Kathy Sullivan. Sullivan was a member of the Opposition Shadow Ministry (1983–84) and (1993–94). She was Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (1997–2000).<ref name=parlbio /> She has been a vocal advocate for an increase in the number of women in parliament.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/cgi-bin/common/printfriendly.pl?/news/politics/2002/08/item20020805102623_1.htm Senate vacancy]</ref> In 2003, she was made a Member of the [[Order of Australia]], for service to the Parliament of Australia and to the community, particularly as an advocate for improved services and conditions affecting women.<ref name=am>[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1042259&search_type=quick&showInd=true SULLIVAN, Kathy], ''It's an Honour'', 2003.</ref> Sullivan was a relatively low-profile MP but in 1993 received national attention when ALP Treasurer John Dawkins taunted her by calling her "sweetheart" in Parliament, which outraged female MPs from Dawkins' own party. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{S-start}} {{S-par|au}} {{S-new| division}} {{S-ttl| title=Member for [[Division of Moncrieff|Moncrieff]] | years=1984–2001}} {{S-aft| after=[[Steven Ciobo]]}} {{S-end}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Sullivan, Kathy | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Martin, Kathy; Martin Sullivan, Kathy; Martin, Kathryn Jean (birth name) | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Australian politician | DATE OF BIRTH = 8 March 1942 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Brisbane, Queensland]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sullivan, Kathy}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Australian House of Representatives]] [[Category:Members of the Australian House of Representatives for Moncrieff]] [[Category:Members of the Australian Senate]] [[Category:Members of the Australian Senate for Queensland]] [[Category:Women members of the Australian House of Representatives]] [[Category:Women members of the Australian Senate]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Recipients of the Centenary Medal]] [[Category:Liberal Party of Australia politicians]]
